title: Collaborative Reflection on Online Education Transition: Autoethnographic Approaches for University Professors

context.prior_knowledge: Experience with Online Learning Environments and Foundational Knowledge in Higher Education
context.additional_context: Aims to deeply understand social and physical changes during the transition to online education in universities, promoting experience sharing and reflection among learners through collaborative autoethnography (CAE)

learning_goals: Learners write a weekly reflective journal in an online learning environment, submit three reflective reports on practice and identity incorporating peer feedback, and achieve at least 15 points (out of 20) on the instructor evaluation rubric (clarity, depth, applicability).
Learners analyze online educational experiences through peer dialogue using the Collaborative Autoethnography (CAE) methodology

Learners identify three social constraints (digital divide, social isolation, decreased learning motivation) and three material constraints (equipment shortage, internet accessibility, unstable power supply) arising during the transition to online education, and write a 1,500-character report proposing two feasible alternatives per constraint. The report must achieve an "excellent" grade in at least two of three rubric criteria (clarity, feasibility, creativity).

resources: Online Collaboration Platform (Google Workspace, Padlet, etc.)

difficulty: Hard - Complex requirements with multiple constraints
